titlestmt.titleproper: Shad, John S. R. John S. R. Shad papers, 1972-1989 (inclusive): A Finding Aid

titlepage.titleproper: Shad, John S. R., 1923-1994. John S. R. Shad papers, 1972-1989 (inclusive): A Finding Aid
titlepage.author: Baker Library
titlepage.p: © 2015 President and Fellows of Harvard College

did.unittitle: John S. R. Shad papers, 1972-1989 (inclusive)
did.abstract: Speeches, congressional testimonies, and briefing materials of John S. R. Shad, mostly created during his tenure as chairman of the United States Securities and Exchange Commission, 1981-1987. The records date from 1972 to 1989.

accessrestrict.p: Some material may be stored offsite. Please contact histcollref@hbs.edu for more information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Cite as: John S. R. Shad papers, Baker Library, Harvard Business School.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note:
bioghist.p: John Sigsbee Rees Shad was born in Brigham City, Utah, on June 27, 1923 and was raised in California. During World War II, Mr. Shad served as a lieutenant (junior grade) in the United States Naval Reserve (1943-1946). After leaving the Navy, Mr. Shad attended the University of Southern California and in 1947 earned a Bachelor of Science degree. He then attended Harvard Business School and was awarded the Master of Business Administration degree in 1949. Later that year, Mr. Shad began a lengthy career on Wall Street. He was a securities analyst for Value Line Inc., an investment advisory service, and subsequently served in the same capacity at Shearson, Hamill & Company. During these years, Mr. Shad earned a law degree from New York University (LL.B., 1959). In 1963, Mr. Shad was recruited as a vice president of E. F. Hutton & Company, which was then a California-based retail brokerage. Working in New York City, Mr. Shad developed E. F. Hutton & Company’s investment banking operations and headed its corporate finance and mergers and acquisitions departments. When he departed in 1981, Mr. Shad was vice chairman of the board of directors of the E. F. Hutton Group, Inc. and was the firm’s third-largest stockholder.

During the 1980 Presidential election, John S. R. Shad chaired the Reagan-Bush Campaign’s New York State Finance Committee. When Reagan took office in 1981, he nominated Mr. Shad for the chairmanship of the United States Securities and Exchange Commission, the independent federal agency charged with protecting investors and maintaining the integrity of the securities markets. Mr. Shad was confirmed by the United States Senate, and then sworn-in on May 5, 1981 as the twenty-second chairman of the S. E. C. He was only the second Wall Street executive appointed to the S. E. C. chairmanship, following forty-seven years after the first chairman, Joseph P. Kennedy.

Under Mr. Shad’s ardent direction, the S. E. C. initiated a deregulatory program that conformed to the Reagan Administration’s efforts to reduce the size of the federal government. In a December 2, 1981 speech before the Securities Industry Association, Mr. Shad stated “I believe industry can regulate itself better than the government can.” Mr. Shad argued that mounting regulatory burdens were harmful to America’s productivity and growth. His S. E. C. worked to reduce and streamline paperwork requirements and to increase automation. The Commission launched EDGAR (Electronic Data Gathering, Analysis and Retrieval System), a computer reporting system, in 1984.

The predominating issues of Mr. Shad’s tenure as S. E. C. chairman were hostile tender offers (or takeovers) and insider trading. Hostile takeovers were increasingly common during the early to mid 1980s, and the issue received considerable popular attention. Mr. Shad was largely untroubled by the increasingly common hostile tender offers. As a steadfast proponent of free markets, Mr. Shad believed that hostile mergers and acquisitions could benefit stockholders, and could also encourage better corporate management. The Securities and Exchange Commission generally did not interfere in hostile tender offers during Mr. Shad’s years as chairman.

Mr. Shad’s S. E. C. took an aggressive stance on insider trading and fraud cases that contrasted with its policies on hostile takeovers and other regulatory issues. Chairman Shad himself promised to come down “on insider trading with hobnailed boots.” Several high-profile insider trading cases made headlines during Mr. Shad’s chairmanship. Most notable was the infamous Drexel Burnham Lambert “junk bond” scandal, which ultimately led to the convictions of Dennis Levine, Ivan Boesky, and Michael Milken.

Over the course of his chairmanship, Mr. Shad’s concern with insider trading and fraud became increasingly personal. In the winter and spring of 1987, he made several speeches that connected the insider trading scandals with a broader issue—the general decline of business leadership and ethics. Mr. Shad was particularly upset that many of those indicted for insider trading were graduates of the country’s leading business and law schools. In March 1987, he made a substantial personal donation to his alma mater, Harvard Business School. Mr. Shad’s gift endowed a program in business ethics and leadership.

When John S. R. Shad resigned from the Securities and Exchange Commission on June 18, 1987, he was the longest-serving chairman to date. Later that month, Mr. Shad was confirmed as the United States Ambassador to the Kingdom of the Netherlands. He resigned his ambassadorship in February 1989 to join Drexel Burnham Lambert, a major Wall Street investment house whose former leadership then faced major corruption charges for racketeering, insider trading, and securities fraud. As part of its settlement agreement with the S. E. C., Drexel Burnham Lambert agreed to name Mr. Shad as its chairman of the board. He served until July 1990. John S. R. Shad died in New York City on July 7, 1994 at the age of seventy-one.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note:
scopecontent.p: The collection consists mainly of copies of the speeches and congressional testimonies that John S. R. Shad gave during his chairmanship of the Securities and Exchange Commission, 1981-1987. Also included are briefing materials gathered to provide Mr. Shad with background information on several regulatory issues that were pending during his tenure at the S. E. C. The records date from 1972 to 1989.

arrangement.head: Series Outline
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in the following series:

did.unittitle: I. Speeches and writings, 1981-1988

scopecontent.p: This series contains copies of official speeches that John S. R. Shad delivered as chairman of the United States Securities and Exchange Commission. The speeches covered a wide variety of issues concerning the S. E. C. and the securities industry, including regulatory policy, deregulation and regulatory reform, investor relations, hostile tender offers, and insider trading. Mr. Shad made these speeches before securities industry groups and academic audiences. There are two copies of most of the speeches—an unmarked official copy and a “speaking copy.” Mr. Shad often made extensive edits and annotations to the speaking copy before using it to deliver his speech. The speech files are arranged chronologically and date from August 1981 to June 1987. The series concludes with a folder of newspaper clippings that quote or mention Mr. Shad (1981-1982) and two opinion pieces he contributed to the Wall Street Journal (1987, 1988).

II. Congressional testimony, 1981-1987

scopecontent.p: This series contains copies of many of the statements that Mr. Shad delivered before Congress. As chairman, Mr. Shad was frequently called upon to testify before the various House and Senate committees and subcommittees that oversee the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Shad’s testimony covered many of the important issues that faced the S. E. C. and the securities industry in the 1980s: regulatory reform and paperwork reduction; the commission’s annual budget request and reauthorization; amendments to laws concerning the S. E. C.’s regulatory authority; the commission’s enforcement efforts, including insider trading cases; and the effect of technology on the operation of the securities markets.

The files contain one or both of the following for each appearance Chairman Shad made before Congress: 1) a written copy of Mr. Shad’s opening statement or oral testimony; 2) a more detailed written statement that was submitted to Congress as official testimony. There are also “speaking copies” of some of the opening statements and oral testimonies; these are edited and annotated copies that Mr. Shad used to deliver his remarks. The testimony files are arranged chronologically.

III. Briefing materials, 1972-1989

scopecontent.p: This series contains a variety of documentation gathered by Mr. Shad’s Securities and Exchange Commission staff to prepare him for appearances before congressional committees. The briefing materials include copies of S. E. C. regulatory announcements and policy statements; advisory committee reports; and comment letters and reports submitted by the securities exchanges, government agencies, and other interested parties. The documents date from 1972 to 1977.

These briefing materials provided Chairman Shad with an overview of numerous regulatory issues that stemmed from changes mandated by the Securities Acts Amendments of 1975. The 1975 Amendments charged the S. E. C. with making dramatic changes in the securities industry, including the development of a National Market System that would change the relationship between the New York Stock Exchange, the regional exchanges, and the National Association of Securities Dealers; changes in the rules regarding off-board trading; and the creation of system-wide automated reporting mechanisms. The specific subjects covered in the briefing materials are: Exchange Off-Board Trading Rules; National Market System; Consolidated Transaction Reporting System; Composite Quotation System; Commission Rates, Membership and Member Trading; and Section 31(b) of the Securities Acts Amendments of 1975. Many of these issues remained unresolved during Mr. Shad’s S. E. C. chairmanship.

The series also contains briefing materials prepared for Mr. Shad during his tenure as chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert. In October 1989, Mr. Shad traveled to Singapore to meet and reassure current and prospective clients. The materials include itineraries, suggested talking points, and background information on the individuals and companies with whom Mr. Shad met.

Securities Exchange Act—Release No. 10969 (August 14, 1974) reproposing Rule 17a-14 for comment.

Securities Exchange Act—Release No. 11288 (March 11, 1975) which announced that the Commission had sent letters to all national securities exchanges formally requesting that such exchanges eliminate all rules or practices which restrict access to or use of quotation information as may be disseminated by such exchanges.

Securities Exchange Act—Release No. 11406 (May 7, 1975) which announced that the Commission had received responses from all national securities exchanges and that all such exchanges had complied with requests made by the Commission relating to the dissemination of quotation information.
Memorandum re: Broker’s Duty of Best Execution, Andrew M. Klein and Bart Friedman to the Advisory Committee on Implementation of a Central National Market System, February 28, 1975.

Securities Exchange Act—Release No.12670 (July 29, 1976) proposing Rule 11 (A)©) 11 which would require national securities exchanges to collect from their specialists and national securities associations to collect from third market makers, quotations in eligible securities for dissemination by such self-regulatory organizations to quotation vendors.
Off-Board Trading Rules
Off-Board Trading Rules Section 11A(c)(4)(A) of the Securities Exchange Act.
Securities Exchange Act—Release No. 11628 (September 2, 1975) noticing a rulemaking proceeding to consider amendment or abrogation of exchange off-board trading rules.
Securities Exchange Act—Release No. 11942 (December 19, 1975) adopting Rule 19c-1 under the Act.
Securities Exchange Act—Release No. 12159 (March 2, 1976) soliciting Public Comment on Issues related to the Development of a Composite Central Limit Order Repository.
Comment letter re: In-House Agency Cross Transactions in Listed Securities by Exchange Members, National Market Advisory Board, September 24, 1976.
Comment letter re: Establishment of a Composite Limit Order Book, National Market Advisory Board, January 28, 1977.
Commission Rates, Membership and Member Trading
Securities Exchange Act—Release No. 9950 (January 16, 1973) adopting Rule 19b-2, pp. 1-50.
Securities Exchange Act—Release No. 9950 (January 16, 1973) adopting Rule 19b-2, pp. 51-100.
Securities Exchange Act—Release No. 9950 (January 16, 1973) adopting Rule 19b-2, pp. 101-150.
Securities Exchange Act—Release No. 9950 (January 16, 1973) adopting Rule 19b-2, pp.151-195.
Securities Exchange Act—Release No. 11203 (January 23, 1975) adopting Rule 19b-3 under the Act, which prohibited exchanges from fixing the rates of commission that their members could charge.
Securities Exchange Act—Release No. 13388 (March 18, 1977) proposing certain rules under Section 11(a) relating to securities transactions by members of national securities exchanges.
Additional Staff Material
Briefing paper: National Market System, by Bart Friedman, April 27, 1977.
Briefing paper: A Composite Limit Order Book: A Current Perspective, by Lee A. Pickard, October 14, 1976.
Briefing paper: Composite Book: A Solution to the Problem of Facilitating Development of a National Market System; by Andrew M. Klein, dated October 14, 1976.
Congressional Hearings—Section 31(b) of the Securities Acts Amendments of 1975: Briefing Book 1
Securities Exchange Act—Release No. 12157 (March 2, 1976) concerning rules of national securities exchanges relating to membership and association with members.

Spokane Stock Exchange: Correspondence from SEC re: Release No. 12157, March 1976.

Securities and Exchange Commission—Release No. 34-13027 (December 1, 1976) concerning Section 31(b) and the rules of self-regulatory organizations.

controlaccess.head: Additional catalog entries
controlaccess.p: The following catalog entries represent persons, organizations, and topics documented in this collection. An entry for each appears in the Harvard On Line Library Information System (HOLLIS) and other automated bibliographic databases. THIS IS NOT AN INDEX.
